column4: how can I reinstall ubuntu w/o loosing my files? Is it possible? It has been failing and I want to reinstall the OS, but I do not want to format
why do you want to reinstall?
unlike Windows, you don't need to reinstall every now and then to keep the OS runnable.

the problem is that sometimes when the computer is booting up, it takes up to 5 minutes, and sometimes it restarts w/o accessing ubuntu. Also when I try to play video/audio files, the movie player fails, and I have to restart one or two times
long boot times might be related to networking issues. What does the movie player say? What do you mean by "w/o accessing ubuntu"?
when I boot up, the screen goes black, and I can only see the cursor, but nothing else. then a few minutes later, the computer restarts
the movieplayer just freezes and goes b&w
hit F1 when you boot (or disable the quiet option the grub boot screen) to see what Linux repots.
*reports

just backup your personal data now, and reinstall Ubuntu. Afterwards, copy your data back into your $HOME...

as to the mplayer problem, you could try another -vo target (see -vo help).

thank you very much for helping me, I really appreciate it, but I think there are tons of error accumulated out there, and I want my computer to be fresh again. I can backup all of my files, so I do not have much to loose but a few hours
but will look at the log file to check the errors, will save them in case I have those errors again
sure thing. Just save your /home stuff and possibly store the list of installed packages.

one last question, after reinstalling, how can I point the system to the new /home partition to save my files? If I do this, can I reinstall ubuntu later in case I have issues like I'm having now w/o loosing my data?
when I said loosing my data, I mean my personal files
for future re-installations, it will be easier if you keep /home on a separate partition.
ok, will have that in mind
you might also be interested in the following:
the thing about a separate partition is, however, that you'll have to make up your mind on how much space you like to dedicated to /home and /.
if you want to do it really right, set up an LVM partition during installation.

mmm, ok, I'm not familiar with it, but will look for info about doing it. For the moment, I need to reinstall windows, and recover the grub. I will reinstall ubuntu later in case I have problems with windows
how many gigs would you recommend me assign to / in order to have lets say about 50 programs installed
after installing ubuntu, of course
it highly depends on the programs. If, for example, you need to use a lot of databases, space can be quickyl consumed.
you want to have someone else in the channel confirm this, but I'd say 5-6 Gigs will be OK.
if you have the space, use 10 just to be sure.
all right. I was thinking about 10 gigs
that'll be totally sufficient.
if we are not talking about a big server installation or something.
all right! Thanks a lot dude
np mate.
don't worry, I consider myself an average computer user
I only need a stable system. I have external hdds where I save my information
you are all set then.

one last question. I have issues with windows viruses and I would like to be able to save my windows and linux information in my hdd. If I format the hdd using an ext3 partition is it possible for a windows virus to corrupt my data on that partition?
a virus capable of writing to such an filesystem will be . But 99.99% of those in the wild don't do that.
if you are affected by a virus, however, you should do an overall clean-up anyway.
I want to separate my linux information from the windows info. Is there any restriction in the files size like in fat (4gbs) under ext partition?
file size depends on the chosen blocksize, but the minimum is 16GB, most likely something like 2TB.
so don't worry.
so basically it means that if I want to save an image of a DVD I will have no problems storing it under the ext3 partition? like in fat, I have tried, but it does not allow files > 4gb
nope, you won't have such a problem under exte.
also, I know there is some sort of driver to read ext partitions under windows. If I convert my entire Hdd to ext partition, will I be able to read/write to the hdd from windows?
I know there is a windows tool that can read ext2/3.
not sure about its reliability, however.
all right
sharing files between Windows and Linux will therefore virtually require a shared FAT partition.
I know this makes virus attacks easier, but you should make sure you don't get any viruses at all anyway.
then you would recommend me to create 2 partitions then? a fat and an ext partition?
how do you want to share data: on the same machine (e.g., access Linux data while Windows is booted), or have something like a file-server?
I only want to store my info in an external hdd and be able to access it either win/linux and be able to carry it everywhere
ok let others correct me if I'm wrong but smb won't help you with that I believe.
that's correct
no prob, have fun.
I'd use something like this: rsync -avrPS /home/myhome/ <destination>
what advantage does the rsync option has against the cp option?
the major advantage is: you can resume the copy process if you have to cancel it for whatever reason.
then I think I will use such command. Thanks
also, it'll preserve file metadata, such as ownership. But if it's just your home, you can do cp as well.
rsync works for sure though.
all right, I have a better feeling for rsync rather than cp
